data.name: Komorebi
data.mainContent:
Komorebi is 'an untranslatable Japanese word, which eloquently captures the effect of sunlight streaming through the leaves of the trees. ... It is the interplay of the aesthetics between the shadows and the leaves and ...trees'. 
This Museum of Modern Art is based on concept of Art as Komorebi. Art as a language. Art as a treasure. These can only be understood and valued if there is understanding and light filtering through. Only with different light can we truly appreciate the diverse world of modern art. 
The museum is made of interlocking geometry, swinging upwards further from the Anderson bridge, it creates different spatial experiences internally and externally while complementing and giving emphasis to the bridge. A play of solid walls and glass panels creates a rhythm of solid and void. Angled planes of wall filters light into the building throughout the museum. The pedestrian roof of the museum that swings up from the ground is uniquely folded to allow light to filter in through clerestory lights while creating steps and slopes for the public to gather and enjoy 360 views at different elevations.

data.name: EC(H)O
data.mainContent:
EC(H)O is a museum catered for two non-standard art forms, botany, and sound. In appearance, EC(H)O is designed to resemble an earpiece that has been plugged into the ground and reclaimed by greenery, reflecting the nature of the artwork within. EC(H)O comprises a multitude of exhibition spaces, ranging large, open areas to small, enclosed spaces. This is due to the inherent requirements for the forms of art displayed within the museum.
The circulation around EC(H)O follows two main paths that deviate from the primary axes used to define the massing of the museum, with smaller branches leading off towards side paths that lead to the various exhibits, hence allowing visitors to explore freely within, around and above the museum building.

data.name: MoMA: The Winding Gallery
data.mainContent:
The Winding Gallery focuses on rejecting the restrictive singular interpretation of a museum.
It aims to disperse the idea of a gallery with large seasonal exhibitions and instead brings pockets of spaces for viewers to weave through the multiplicity of artworks. The museum would become grounds for fluidity, where the viewers would be able to move and interact with artworks in any sequence or path.
​Thus, no exhibition, art installation, circulation or method would be the same. Visitors would always be surprised by the different scenes whenever they visit, and enhancing the museum experience for people from all walks of life to allow for new immersion into various art styles.

data.name: Interweaving Places
data.mainContent: While immersed in art, I envisioned a MoMA that connects to the site, allowing visitors to appreciate the surrounding places. Heavily inspired by the artist, Sopheap Pich and his weaving rattan pieces, I designed this MoMA with the intention of interweaving the surrounding places into this MoMA, bringing the visitors to places outside of the MoMA.

data.name: Singularity
data.mainContent:
What will you miss after you die? The future holds so much possibility that it overwhelms us with regret. The completion of the Zeitpyramid in the 3183 AD, the recovery of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone in 22000, and the collision of our galaxy with Andromeda in 2.5 million years, are events far flung into the future beyond the reach of our brief existence.
The fear is not that of death, but of regret. In the year 30XX, progression of humanity has plateaued. While the world no longer suffers from food shortages or poverty, technology and culture has reached a stagnation. Many start to ponder and question the reason for their existence. Maybe it was by pure chance or through the will of the unknown, a collective of thinkers came to the same conclusion; our existence merely serves as a vessel for the universe to grow, and now it is time to assimilate and return to the singularity.
The collective inspired others and soon grew into a congregation. The followers believed that the singularity is an entity beyond humanity, yet do not worship it. Instead, they wrote tenets for subsequent followers; The Five Forms of Assimilation. The followers document their lives through a digital journal, capable of recording every sensation, thought and emotion. The knowledge and wisdom of humanity will then be returned upon death to bring us closer towards the Singularity.

data.name: Open Library
data.mainContent:
In 2075, disinformation, a form of information misuse through an intentional and deliberate fabrication of information to manipulate and deceive has become a severe problem. While the Internet brought much freedom across the world, empowered many individual voices and provided an avenue for an unprecedented ability to communicate ideas and opinions, it also carried the insidious ability to distort, to mislead and to communicate falsehood, produce hatred and instability. And as such, this creates confusion and erodes public perceptions and trust.
As a community, we cannot stop all public voice/opinion just because there is the danger in the potential misuse of communication. In democracy, we still need to experience a plurality of voices and opinions for the further development and progress of society. However, we also need to have the skills and resources to help us gauge the veracity of those voices. We must “use technology and regulation to restore democratic accountability” (UK government's “Disinformation and ‘fake news': Final Report”)
In order so that proper and safe communication in the community is restored, the library is repurposed into a safe and regulated platform for the expression of public opinion unlike the wild and uncontrolled freedom of the internet. The library serves as a space for public to come to record down and voice their opinions on issues that they are concern of in a standardised and open manner.

data.name: Tripartite Library
data.mainContent:
In the year 2075, development in society and technology led to the creation of self-aware machines. The implication of this created being has on religion is very significant. Artificial Intelligence (AI) having gained sentience shook the very core of Christianity as it questions the fundamental basis of what the religion is based on.
What would happen if AI wants to join the religion and be a believer? Will they be denied or accepted? Theology has to keep abreast of these societal developments and find answers to these new issues in the religious texts of old. As such, a library has been created for AI to learn more about Christianity with the help of theologians who act as this library's librarians. At the same time, the theologians can learn more about AI and study to answer these questions in the new context of the times.
This library stores with Christian resources produced throughout time. It contains precious Christian artefacts, like the ark, original scriptures and the dead sea scrolls. It also houses the largest collection of physical and digital bibles of different versions, translations and editions, academic journals, music and sermon recordings. The library is designed for AI to traverse the space virtually through electrical wirings. As they traverse through, each chamber of space brings them through different thematic experiences of parables and stories of the bible. The AI have access to the entire database of the e-library and are also able to use robotic arms to view physical books. VR pods are available to provide AI with an avatar body as they converse and worship with the theologian librarians. The library also offers meditation rooms to provide the librarians with a quiet environment to seek God and worship individually.

data.name: Dream Theatre
data.mainContent:
The project explores a speculative world where most of humanity have lost the ability to dream. Cities have become mundane and uncreative, purely functional and utilitarian, stripped of the many stimulating features it once had. For the minority, the 'dreamers'; those who have still remained the ability to dream, in turn created large theatres tucked in canyons and valleys, far away from the cities - and they called it Dream Theatres.
A Dream Theatre is where the dream worlds are projected for non-dreamers to experience, they enable non-dreamers to experience dreams again, as well as help those who don't understand the concept of dreams to be fully immersed in the experience. The performer, a non-dreamer, is given the opportunity to experience the dream on stage, whilst an audience watches him/ her move around in their dream.
The  Dream  Theatre   helps  to  share  the  culture  of  dreams to people who have either lost their ability to dream or who don't understand the concept of dreams altogether. Dreams are experienced with the help of virtual reality, and displayed as a performance with the help of augmented reality. After the dream experience, the performer is invited to dream perpetually for the remainder of their life inside a dream bunker, without contact with the outside world. The Dream Theatre handles the archival as well as the performative aspects of dreams, and for both non-dreamers and dreamers, introduces an experience like no other.

data.name: The Dualistic Museum
data.mainContent:
The modern city is dead, it has fallen victim to utility. As humans tend to negotiate living with the ocean, functionality of cities has become a major force of nature in this new Anthropocene epoch. Functionalism is adopted in the ideology of rebuilding the civilization, the idea serves as a new approach to urbanism. Society yearns for the notion of diversity, the boredom of being the ‘sameness' triggers the intention of people to interact. A call for action to reconstruct the synergy of the society is needed.
The placement of the site is a silent demonstration against power/panopticism, it is a form of critique towards future social space in the context of functionalist society and its cultural and political poles. The museum seeks to establish a dialogue of dichotomy between cultural revolution (fluid) and political control (static), which is parallel with the collective intentions to liberate cultural discourse from the datum of power. megastructure is sought to fuse the elements of static and fluid coherently while allowing user to enter from any point of entry. Therefore, the museum spatial organization is envisioned from the perception of segregation between static and fluid space, the formality of static space and informality of fluid space is manifested into the notion of stability and instability, respectively. The level of stability in the ‘apparatus' – architecture is defined by the discipline of the arrangement with references to the integrity of the grid. To illustrate the following statement, the stability region symbolises the formal planning of the functionalist city while the instability region symbolises the informal planning of social space in the functionalist city. The thresholds between both elements are accentuated by a series of experiential vertical corridor which connects both functionally. The experiential vertical corridor is a projection of galleries space which recollects the moments of civilization.

data.name: The River of Falls
data.mainContent:
A world of arid deserts and harsh cold nights. In such a place, the native people have only one refuge - The River of Falls. It is the only place with a large enough body of water to sustain their population, where they are born and grow up until they come of age to explore the arid deserts. In such a place, water and life are held sacred; natives gather to bring in new life, to celebrate, and to mourn when others pass on. This River is the beginning and the end of their lives.
The cemetery is a micro-view of this culture, it is a space for the people to bring their deceased loved ones to move on to the digital plane, where they would live on in a place without rushing for survival. The living can visit this digital plane to meet the deceased, to let go of the pain and to gain inner peace.
This experience is created to project a novel method of a cemetery without requiring physical space for the deceased, yet allowing for the living to still pay respects and interact with the deceased. The cemetery becomes a place of meeting, catching up, all within another plane. This brings up a possible way to revise the current crowded cemetery spaces without clearing more land for burying.

data.name: Creative Quarters
data.mainContent:
The lack of dedicated developments in Singapore for creative startups to work in necessitates the provision of a workspace that encourages greater productivity and creativity. Startups involve high intensity sporadic work that poses negative impacts on one's physical and mental health, especially with working from home where there lacks a transition from 'work state' to 'home state'. 
The project responds to the rich and stimulating site by elevating the "garage" above the ground, preserving the existing old Mowbray Camp buildings, greenery and the canal. It mediates the issue by introducing third places integrated with the workspace, allowing easy disengagement from one's task to respite. Living spaces, sky gardens, void decks, and landscape are redefined into productive workspaces. The office park introduces nature as a third place for respite or a mediating buffer between the low intensity home and the high intensity office. To sustain this relationship, residents also engage in maintenance works to actively contribute and give back to nature.

data.name: Bio-Flux
data.mainContent:
The design intention started by questioning what are the relationship between housing and the city. The housing project is strategically sited within the confluences of different institution and therefore, the housing project aims to rethink the typology of residential college in order to facilitate the cross fertilisation of knowledge between occupants. Demographically, the housing project is targeting individuals and small families as potential occupants.
The housing scheme integrates the typology of slab blocks and courtyard into a singular housing entity. The new typology reinforces the concept of bridging connections to different occupants by externalising the living environment of every unit. These externalised 3rd spaces are established as a series of shared spaces to encourage collaboration and interaction to allow the influx of intellectual exchange.
In conclusion, the proposed housing scheme is a critique to existing housing typologies for being a mono-functional housing type. Therefore, the scheme seeks to explore the versatility of different housing type in order to be able to adapt as a productive asset in the future of living.

data.name: Baptism Of Water
data.mainContent: Inspired by the water that was used to put out the fire that destroyed one of France's national monuments, termed the ‘Baptism of Fire', the ‘Baptism of Water' seeks to cleanse and provide a renewal to the Gothic Cathedral through the form of a wave symbolizing a new beginning for the Parisian icon.

data.name: Intervention à l' unité d'habitation
data.mainContent:
Taking the form of a single rectangular block, the Unité d'Habitation was designed as an innovative housing type designed to provide its inhabitants with a balance of community and individual amenities, while providing mass housing within a relatively small building footprint. The block would be oriented with the units on the long edge facing east-west to maximise sunlight into the units, and have wide common corridors in the middle of the levels that would provide access to the L-shaped units on both sides.
In its first iteration in Marseille, 1952, the development provided a range of facilities including shops, educational facilities, public hotel and a restaurant, all housed within a retail level located in the middle of the block. In addition, the communal rooftop terrace was designed with the resident's needs in mind, containing a running track, children's paddling pool and children's art school.
For the building in Nantes-Reze, 1955, the building was designed to sit in the natural landscape of water and trees without any loss of the agricultural land surrounding it.
However, in order to house the 321 apartments within a smaller footprint, the version of the Unité at Reze lost the retail level found in Marseille, and the rooftop was reduced to housing only a children's school. The units themselves were also smaller and lost the double volume space which let a great amount of light into the living spaces.

data.name: Scaffold: Reconstruction of the post fire Cathédrale Notre Dame de Paris
data.mainContent: This intervention seeks to celebrate the fire of Notre Dame by recognising the changes the fire made to the cathedral, while also preserving the surviving portions of the cathedral, and continuing to remember the original roof. This new space will provide new public spaces for the city, giving even more recreational areas for the people, and allowing the cathedral to become a social hub once again, instead of simply being a tourist attraction.

data.name: Restoration | Notre Dame: Celebration of History
data.mainContent: The design for the Notre Dame roof restoration is a celebration of the cathedral's remarkable legacy. The former 'forest' of the previous roof is exteriorised in all its beauty as a lenticular truss, creating an interior 2-level suspended library as well as a bridge exhibition deck. Additionally, this design serves as a critique of the current restoration efforts, to build in a more sustainable manner.

data.name: The Isolation Room
data.mainContent:
The Isolation Room is an extension of the 1926 Villa Cook that was designed by Le Corbusier. The Isolation Room is a response to modern day home requirements, such as a resting space for the ill who are stricken with highly infectious diseases, a work-from-home office, as well as a much needed quiet space for introspection in our fast-paced world. The intervention takes place above the existing structure, adding an additional level, which nicely aligns with the height of the neighbouring buildings.
The design of Villa Cook and the neighbouring buildings has been left relatively untouched for close to a century. As such, there is an opportunity to offer a meaningful intervention to reflect present day needs. The use of contemporary natural materials, such as rammed earth and wood contrast starkly with the sea of white concrete and black metal, charting the way forward for a more sustainable future.

data.name: Eras
data.mainContent: Eras is a proposal for the restoration of the Notre Dame that repurposes its roof into a space for learning and exposure of eras. It combines different mediums for visitors to learn about history and Paris through the lens of time, consisting of a historical exhibit of the religion as well as the Notre Dame and a digital media exhibition portraying local scenes of Paris from any time periods in the eyes of Parisians themselves. The transition of mediums which the exhibits use from physical to digital artifacts intertwines the ancient and the present, utilizing technology to show experiences of Paris. The design of Eras is inspired by contemporary takes on Gothic architecture, taking into consideration continuity and coherence with respect to the existing Gothic architecture of the Notre Dame.

data.name: Latter Rain
data.mainContent:
God's word is symbolised as raindrops. The Latter Rain symbolises showers of blessings. It will be a time of the harvest, a time of manifestation of blessings. This intervention is centered around the collection and recycling of rainwater. The roof structure collects rainwater and channels it to the baptism pool at the new rooftop garden chapel. Water is also channelled to the water plaza below through a mesh of pipes running along the sides of the cathedral, symbolising an overflow of God's blessings. The collected water is also used to cool down the space, irrigate the landscape and water stores in case of fires.
In contrast to the serious and rigid nature of a traditional Catholic church, this intervention converts the upper volume of the Notre Dame into a restful performance and event space. This gives the cathedral a duality. The space can also be used for informal church gathering spaces to create a less intimidating space for people to learn about Christ

data.name: Memoirs of Spaces
data.mainContent:
It's year 3000. Sun radiation turned more harmful than ever due to ozone depletion. Land is no longer habitable due to mutative elements, forcing humans to live 10 km under the sea level. Just when people are losing hope, scientists developed a species that could reverse the condition, enabling a museum to open closer to the water surface. Using Virtual Reality, the museum reminds people that the world is beyond the cramped space they are living in.
Inspired by Charles and Ray Eams' “Powers of Ten” and Bruno Latour's “Facing Gaia”, the experience is designed to remind humans about the ‘bigger hole' and concerns human-nature relationship. The museum takes visitor through a journey from the bottom of the ocean to the outer space, allowing humans to virtually traverse the land as much as they could before Anthropocene took place.

data.name: Checkpoint
data.mainContent: Revitalisation of the waterfront to Ghim Moh. Marking new entry points into the old site, creating new public spaces at the PCN.

data.name: Middle Grounds
data.mainContent:
Living with nature is often touted as the future of living in view of increasing ecological and environmental awareness among the public. There have been many attempts at realizing this lifestyle through the vertical integration of flora into urban developments with varying degrees of success.
Building on the southern edge of Clementi Forest, we envision an urban housing development that champions the notion of living with nature in a contemporary setting. Leveraging on the site's steep topography, the site is vertically stratified with elevated urban networks that host programs at different datum heights, providing varying levels of access to nature that is rare in contemporary mass housing.
This development posits a future where the secondary forest that has been built upon has rehabilitated through the reintroduction of existing tree species back on site.

data.name: Inter-gen Terraces
data.mainContent: Inter-gen Terrace serves as a central node of social amenities within the precinct. It seeks to break the formal segregation and promote intergenerational co-living between the two ends of the spectrum by integrating medical care and childcare services into a single shared space. Alongside the communal space between the residential towers, it provides the opportunity to introduce casual collision between children and the elderly through common facilities. Using water as the medium for social activity, Inter-gen Terrace revitalizes the existing natural stream and introduce an artificial waterfall to bring the community together in achieving the common goal of restoring the Dover forest.

data.name: Fractal Forest
data.mainContent:
Fractal Forest seeks to echo the old kampung spirit in current Ghim Moh through the additional of new communal living spaces, mixing both old and new buildings. Located between the Ghim Moh market and the park connector, it seeks to be an interconnecting link between these two bustling areas.
Each fractal contributes to the larger whole of a vast forest, an endless pattern connecting communal shared spaces together to form a community under the large canopy. Many public spaces are designed on the ground and roof plane as these serves as an important platform to form strong communities. Strong communities are critical because they are often an important source of social connection and a sense of belonging. Participating in a community bonded by attitudes, values and goals is essential to enjoying a fulfilling life.

data.name: ONBOARD
data.mainContent:
ONBOARD is a pavilion designed to showcase the SUTD x SIA Upcyling Initiative which focuses on the creative repurposing and upcycling of retired commercial aircraft parts and materials.
FORM A380 plexiglass panels, aluminum frames and upcycled items come together to create a mutating pavilion which speaks about reconfigurability both in the long term, because of its circularity, and in the short term, thanks to its use of digital technologies,structural approach and modularity.
EXPERIENCE The ONBOARD pavilion offers people a place to experience or even experiment with the aesthetics and textures of upcycling when they interact with its resultant structure, space and light. It is an immersive experience within a completely upcycled environment which aims to project an upcycled future world.
UPCYCLING OVERVIEW The pavilion's ease in reappropriating itself into different site typologies and scales highlights its role as a petri dish for a creative and normalised upcycling culture.

data.name: Volant Visions
data.mainContent:
Volant Visions is an exploration in utilising computational simulation and advancements in technology as tools to promote the concept of upcycling and sustainability. Functioning not only as a display set, Volant Visions itself aims to be a display of the new possibilities of sustainable and circular design.
Through the use of PLA filament and 3D printing technologies, parts of Volant Visions can be easily reproduced and adapted for other uses and scales through a wide range of 3D printers, from commercially available tabletop printers to much larger industrial printers. We imagine that this design system can be extended from small scale projects like desk displays to much larger applications like facades or screen walls, for which the PLA filament can be replaced with other 3D printable weather resistant materials like glass and metal.

data.name: WEAVE
data.mainContent:
Inspired by the idea of flight, we came across weaver bird nests which are put together with a smorgasbord of materials while creating a cozy resting space that provides some privacy and shade. Hence, we endeavoured to weave wood and windows salvaged from retired aircraft together with colourful recycled cotton cord. In an indoor environment like a library or an exhibition space, our structure is meant to be a comfortable seating area for visitors of all ages, from children to elderly.
These modular mini benches can be arranged both horizontally and vertically, inviting visitors to stack them as they please, to form either seatings with backrest, semi-closed structures for more privacy or even as playground blocks. These modules have been designed to use materials that are upcycled, recycled and, easily recyclable, forming a circular loop where material waste is minimized. Moreover, the three parts -- the wood, windows and cord -- can be easily assembled by individual users, and with multiple units, can be put together to cater for use in larger scale events and spaces. When many modules come together, a prismatic installation materialises, making an interior space more vibrant, providing visual delight to visitors, and encouraging them to interact with these modules. Through this, we hope to be able to introduce the spirit of upcycling to users, while also allowing a level of participation on their part.
We based our design on two main principles: Eliminating waste and pollution, and circulating products and materials. By optimising our design through physical and digital prototyping to minimise use of additional material like wood and using materials that are recycled (i.e. cotton cord), we breathed new life into pieces of aviation history (i.e. airplane windows) by turning them into value-added furniture.

data.name: Filter Farm
data.mainContent:
Current discourse on ecological services associates its provisions to the performance of our planet's natural ecosystems and allocates human as a passive beneficiary. The current narrative tends to associate urbanity as disruptive to the natural regulatory ecological processes and associates natural imbalance to the unavoidable functions of cities.
Our project challenges the notion of dissonance between cities and nature by integrating the two systems into a singular ecosystem that has the potential to self-regulate.
Through the agroecological approach to farming plants, we use human consumption to regulate the flow of excess nitrogen and carbon through the ecosystem. The buildings on Alexandra Woodlands are a series of self-regulating scaffolds that farm cycles of nitrogen and carbon absorbent plantations, responding to the fluctuating nitrogen and carbon content in the air.

data.name: Bio-Bridge
data.mainContent: As our name suggests, we tried as much as possible to use sustainable materials in our bridge as well as in the fabrication of it. We used FLAM (fungal-like adhesive material) as an alternative for 3D printed nodes, jute ropes as a replacement for the steel cable, as well as medium density fibreboard to replace plywood. Moreover, during the fabrication process, we used leftover blue foam from past assignments to prop up our structure. In addition, using digitally fabricated 'node rulers', we were able to hand mould the chitin-cellulose mixture onto their nodal placements. With a central-webbed design, the bridge does not compromise on its structure, optimising load at the centre and translating it into tension at the jute ropes and compression on the dowels perpendicular to the deck. During the final presentation, our structure managed to withstand 60 kg of weights, before breaking under the pressure. It had minor deflection at 50kg, the amount of weight it needed to minimally hold, indicating that our structure satisfies both its ultimate limit state and serviceability limit state.

data.name: Re-Growth
data.mainContent:
Cultural imagery of bees conjures our association of the species as unfriendly honey-making hive-nesting creatures that swarm and attack people with their stingers. This misrepresentation is detrimental to the resilience of our urban and natural ecosystems. More than labelling bees as unwelcome pests, the crisis may result from the lack of public advocates to conserve natural bee habitats at the pressures of rapid urban development. Research on urban wildlife points to finite food source as the single most limiting factor in expanding urban biodiversity. Bees are one of the smallest denominators life-form, a close bottom of the food chain. They provide an invaluable ecological service which helps the forest biodiversity to thrive through the pollination of flowers which in turn produce fruits for other species to enjoy and are themselves food source to other animal species.
Building on Alexander Woodlands, we envision an urban infrastructure that accelerate bee population growth. This infrastructure augment existing natural systems to supply consistent flow of nutrient enriched water for flowering plant cultivation and aligns human activities to provide the logistical operations that enable the intensification of blooming periods. This supercharged, ultra-dense haven for bees would create a new form urban forest with diversity and intensity not possible without such artificial scaffolding.

data.name: The Urban Shrub Expansion
data.mainContent:
The Urban Shrub Expansion explores the possibilities of shrubs as the new main mode of planting to encourage greenery growth instead of trees, bridging the gap between the inside and outside of the site, Alexandra Woodland, as its centre.
Shrubs are overlooked in urban habitat restoration even though they are the main factor in multiplying, diversifying and thickening the greenery growth from grassland into forests. We believe that this should not be the case, and aim to educate the people on the importance shrubs are within our site building.
This project also explores a connective habitat network utilising shrubs that would branch out and extend from our site as the centre, so as to strengthen the green corridors that are currently mostly isolated and disjointed from each other due to the urban concrete jungle factor. This network can be achieved through a porous building that allow for plant growth within it, preventing the building from becoming a deterrent of shrub expansion.

data.name: Intervention | The Convent of La Tourette
data.mainContent: The Convent of La Tourette was built to be a self-contained world for a community of silent monks. Working with the general giving nature of monasteries, the provocative greenhouse extension aims to provide these monks a green space for them to enjoy the process of creating and working towards sustainability.

data.name: Sitting Conveniences
data.mainContent:
Airports are notoriously rigid about the way passengers interact with furniture and rest. We decided to challenge this reality and restore the freedom of movement. The final form was derived parametrically with reference to the various sitting and lying positions one might assume.
To construct this amorphous form, we borrowed strap cutters from leather working to cut the conveyor belts into straps that can be woven together on top of a wooden frame. Soft and pliable, the final structure mimics the sensation of one being suspended in a hammock, creating a sense of separation for users from the environment around them.
Situated at the center of the lounge near the windows, we hope to offer the therapeutic view of passing planes alongside the ability to lie down for longer periods, and quick access to upright seats facing the main corridor.

data.name: Regrowth
data.mainContent:
Throughout the long history of the Notre Dame, from the Huegenot riots in the 1500s to being used as a warehouse in the 1800s, the Notre Dame has not been changeless throughout time. However, we also see that with these events of destruction also spurred new opportunities for the rejuvenation and regrowth of the Notre Dame. Regrowth is a project that sees the event of the fire as just another mark in the Notre Dame's ongoing history and an opportunity to ignite new growth in the Notre Dame.
The original name of the roof, 'The Forest', is reinterpreted into a space for both the literal regrowth of nature in the roof as well as a hub for cultural regrowth as a public space for the creation and display of art in different forms. This is implemented through the use of a timber superstructure which has the permeability and flexibility to evolve with the everchanging needs of the people and plants. These elements are anchored on an underhanging gallery that recounts the history of the Notre Dame as well as viewpoints out to iconic landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower and the River Seine, grounding the space in the past, present and future of the Notre Dame and Paris.

data.name: Beach Lamp
data.mainContent:
Our Luminaire embodies the upcycling methodology in its construction and material choice. Constructed with natural and sustainable materials such as raw wood, bio resin and seashells, it captures the colors of the seaside and emanates it throughout your bedroom in the form of an ambient desk lamp.
The aim of this luminaire is to showcase and tap in on the possibilities of the objects which are left on the beach (and degrade overtime) by giving them a new life. The lamp allows the user to appreciate nature and the beauty and textures of natural materials through its atmospheric and calming presence.

data.name: Heart in a Heart
data.mainContent:
Housing in new Ghim Moh is one which extends old Ghim Moh's social center across new Ghim Moh and beyond. This project has four primary primary focuses which are:
1) Connecting young and old Ghim Moh residents
2) Bridging old and new economic markets
3) Extending mature forests into new Ghim Moh
4) Launching Ghim Moh's heartland businesses.

data.name: Wellness
data.mainContent:
Wellness is a residential development that contains residential towers and a mixed-use residential and commercial podium called Terracing Generations. Terraces are a form of agriculture that maximizes the use of their steep terrain. It captures water _owing down, thereby retaining nutrients in the soil. Similarly, Terracing Generations is a residential site that encapsulates this concept. With respect to its context, TG emphasizes its elderly residents' while promoting wellness and active living.
Just like terraces, generations are built above one another with the elderly's families living above them in the residential towers. This empowers the elderly with independent living while enabling them to be close together. Visually, the building is also connected vertically through the voids. This allows for residents to catch a glimpse of communal activities taking place with the hopes of drawing people out of their homes. Greater community engagement helps to prevent dementia in the elderly and promotes wellbeing.
TG is designed specifically with many gathering spaces and activity spaces surrounded by greenery. This facilitates social activities for the elderly residents and is good for their health and psychological stimulations. Wellness being the entire development's main emphasis, there is also a large focus on prevention. As such, healthy living activities are promoted. This includes spaces for exercise, walking trials and many green spaces for immersion with nature. With the idea of generations in mind, elderly residents at Wellness help to take care of the youngest demographic, the children, as well. Like how nutrients are captured in terraces, this interaction among generations with the idea of the elderly passion their knowledge down to the next. As such, the next generation is built up on them as the foundation of society.

data.name: The Urban Stitch
data.mainContent: The Urban Stitch looks to foster a new relationship between the old and new. By interweaving and interlocking into existing buildings in Ghim Moh, it creates a connection in space. These connections further serve as intermediate vestibules where incoming homeowners and long-time Ghim Moh residents can find meaningful activities and opportunities to share and bond over. Residential unit designs are modulated to create shared social spaces between units, with agricultural areas to connect local activity to the new agricultural centre at the repurposed school. Through this gradient of public spaces, activities and a ground-scraping housing typology, we begin to see the stitching between the upcoming agricultural zone and mature residential areas, the incoming and existing residents, as well as the new housing with the existing structures. Through these means, this project envisions a new way to approach the development of housing and the redevelopment of mature estates.

data.name: Regrowth
data.mainContent: Regrowth aims to integrate the existing Ulu Pandan Community Centre to a decentralised arrangement throughout the site, bringing greater connectivity to the Rail Corridor to create more sustainable living and enhance the existing slab block through the introduction of new housing typologies and social spaces for a new way of living.

data.name: Flora Scapes
data.mainContent: As a co-living community that overlooks the forest and canal, Flora Scapes tackles the issues of loneliness and affordable home ownership by bringing elderly, families and young adults together to share resources and forge bonds, reingniting the kampung spirit in a conducive manner.

data.name: Unspoken Interactions
data.mainContent: This project attempts to understand the current strain between Singaporeans, as the general public, and the international working community within Singapore, within a housing space.

data.name: Wellness2
data.mainContent: This project aims to propose a new way of approaching how to provide for the againg population in Singapore. Wellness is a residential development that contains residential towers and a mixed-use residential and commercial podium. The residential towers serve as to provide a living space for families who wish to stay close to their elderly family members, but as well as to provide a new way of living in and around nature.

data.name: dis(connect)
data.mainContent:
The Farrer Road x Dunearn Road Flyover is a complex site that comprises of 3 distinct layers (flyover, ground level and underpass with canal) and 4 unique quadrants. The site is a highly urban area with a busy junction that caters to the neighbourhood and the city. With the heavy traffic in the surrounding, pedestrians often feel uncomfortable when interacting with the spaces beneath the flyover.
This master-plan aims to improve on the flood management system by articulating the landscape. It also seeks to alleviate the disconnection felt by users of the site by introducing transitional spaces and buffers.
Additionally, the masterplan acts as a launchpad for individual interventions to occur. These projects explore the possibilities that can happen in tangent with the masterplan at key locations, with the intention of improving the neighbourhood while retaining its genius loci.

data.name: Co-Nectar
data.mainContent:
Co-Nectar is an adaptable and modular set of building blocks that can be designed by Youths, for Youths, to better connect Somerset Belt in terms of accessibility, people and allow it to always be relevant to the Youths of the generation. Somerset belt hopes to renew itself as a space for Youths today, however it is currently too disconnected in its physical, community and time aspects. It is physically disconnected due to many sections being troublesome to access in situations of rain or shine. It is disconnected in its community as Youth interest groups are segregated along the belt and as such does not promote growth in the Youth community. Finally, it is disconnected in its time aspect as it is unable to renew itself to be relevant to Youths due to its built limitations.
Co-Nectar is a set of modules with customizable palettes that can not only cater to different Youth interest groups, but can also be weaved between existing built spaces. Through time, these modules can adapt to Youth's changing needs no matter the built changes of Somerset Belt as a whole, ensuring that Co-Nectar will always be a growing hub attracting Singapore's Youths to Somerset Belt even in the future.

data.name: Kinetic Forest
data.mainContent:
Kinetic Forests is a project that returns the agency of design and activities of the Somerset Youth Belt to the youth to allow for the wide diversity of their interests and needs to be met. Through the study and use of passive and active escapism, the Kinetic Forests are designed as environments that the youth can use to augment both their spatial and sensory experiences in Somerset. These physical environments are mirrored digitally to give youth access at anytime to collaborate in groups to design and plan out their own personalised spaces. When this digital world is downloaded and manifested into Somerset for the weekend, the youth are then able to explore an everchanging, new world created through their own means.
Through this process, the Kinetic Forests provide both a space in which youth can find comfort and relief and also a tool through which they begin to feel empowered to craft the reality they desire in both Somerset and their own lives.

data.name: STEPS
data.mainContent: Located in the Plantation District of Tengah town, this project sits in front of the bay, surrounded by the upcoming HDBs. Extending the proposed park, STEPS is a playfield that seeks to connect the plantation strip, HDB and the bay through a multitude of sports, both conventional and unconventional. Through the staggering and stepping of the landform, play surfaces are created both horizontally and vertically, challenging the norm of sports and seeking to raise awareness for the unconventional yet upcoming popular sports.

data.name: Roundabouts
data.mainContent: Roundabouts is a comprehensive proposal for the Tengah Town Play Field project that contributes fresh ideas and a larger conversation regarding the role of a sport facility within a HDB heartland context. It is envisioned as a pit-stop within a park with a colocated emphasis, integrating daily heartland lifestyle into sports facilities, to invite participation and intermixing of different user groups. The multi-functional and multi-mix facilities allow sports and other uses to be multiplied, intermixed, ensuring a future-proof sports facility that can adapt to future changes.

data.name: A Million Holes
data.mainContent: As one of the world's busiest airports by international passenger and cargo traffic, Changi Airport has a constant flow of people of all ages and from all walks of life. In order to intrigue and draw transit passengers into the transit lounge, we designed a highly stimulating spectacle contrasting to the whole of Terminal 2. Using the perforated panels that originated from the old Terminal 2's ceiling, we created a fascinating facade along the entire stretch of the transit lounge. Not only does this facade provide some privacy to the people in the lounge, but it also invites people travelling on the travelators to explore the lounge. Using projection mapping and pose estimation, people traversing outside the lounge can enjoy a customised interaction with the panels via the displayed lighting effects on them. Furthermore, people inside the lounge can also be entertained by a beautiful display of vibrant, colourful lights that are created due to the movement of people outside the lounge.

data.name: WeCare
data.mainContent:
Often having their own needs go unnoticed for the sake of their care recipients, caregivers can find themselves feeling invisible, lacking the social support networks to deal with their daily stresses. Hence, the Caregiver Support Network is an initiative by WeCare@Marine Parade to alleviate some of these physical, emotional and financial stressors by providing a caregiver clubhouse for lower-income groups.
Working off the research previously done by NUS students to understand the needs of these caregivers, this project works alongside WeCare to propose a design option for this clubhouse based on four main principles, a symbolic transition of rest for the caregivers, varying levels of flexibility of the care recipient zone, encouraging conversations whilst still providing privacy and creating a flexible space for a variety of uses. The choice of lighting and materials also plays a part in creating a warm, inviting atmosphere for the caregivers.
Lastly, as this space is a tenancy within the larger Marine Parade Community Care Hub, the space outside of this clubhouse has also been designed to serve as a casual gathering space for both caregivers and the general community. The distinct lighting feature over the space serves as both wayfinding in the underground linkway, as well as an homage to the soon to be renovated Marine Parade CC.

data.name: Deafspace@DDDK
data.mainContent: At the entrance of Marine Parade Community Care Hub lies Singapore's first deaf friendly underground space. In collaboration with DonDonDonki, who hopes to employ Deaf employees and promote inclusiveness, we create a deaf inclusive spatial experience for all based on DeafSpace architectural design guidelines by Gallaudet University.

data.name: Starchamps Playground
data.mainContent:
Children are their own unique individuals with their own likes and interests. Yet, the one thing that they all have in common is that they all Play. Play brings together these children. It is the best way for learning and developing. Through the different types of play, these children come together and become one. It is the simplest yet most effective tool in creating interactions between the children.
Located within an underground linkway that forms the Marine Parade Community Care Hub, Starchamps Playground is one of a kind - it is an inclusive indoor playground that seeks to provide a safe and fun space for all children to play in, specifically children with autism. By tapping on the four types of play: solitary, parallel, associative, and cooperative, the playground allows the children to play at their own pace, individually or with others.
Food and beverage shops located opposite the playground allow parents to rest while their children play. Steps next to the playground that resemble the mural facade of the Marine Parade CC serve as seating and a gathering space.

data.name: The Hidden Cave Respite
data.mainContent:
This project focuses on bringing the caregivers and care receipients to a space where they are able to let go of their daily routines and hectic work, to rest up for a while and recharge themselves. It proposes another method of understanding space, using lighting and ceiling division instead of having permanent ground dividers that takes up space and is not flexible enough to cater to various activity types.
Utilising the concept of a cavern, pockets of spaces are carved out using lighting and movable dividers to cater to different preferences, whether the visitors want a private space for resting or a mingling social space to catch up and bond with other caregivers. Care receipients are well taken care of by the staff stationed within the lounge and thus, care givers can have a peace of mind during their stay there.
This lounge space is designed to be a change in atmosphere from the care givers daily lives, a physical embodiment of a new and unknown space to help them embrace their relaxation time.

data.name: Curly Cove
data.mainContent: CURLY COVE is a series of open sports coves integrated into a constructed landform structure that is Tengah's Play Field Facility. The structure is punctuated by pit stops connected with a main meandering path, offering users a scramble of programmes to informally engage in - from agricultural activities to exciting sports spaces - wherever they wander to.  Tengah's bay is invited into CURLY COVE in oases along the playfield's boundary with mini islands scattered across the waterbodies, allowing for an intermix of hybrid land and water activities. CURLY COVE aims to be a welcoming space - a neighbourhood cove - with informal and beautiful mixed-use spaces for any user, of any age and ability.

data.name: Unearthed
data.mainContent: This project aims to revitalise Singapore's sports scene by blurring the lines between the different sports, allowing for experiences to intermix through line of sight and proximity.

data.name: Blamp
data.mainContent: To combine is a interaction focused luminaire. Drawing inspirations from wooden puzzle boxes, parts can be exchanged to affect the overall light expression. Interchanging external blocks with different materials and colours allow great flexibility in the expression of light and textures. The simplicity of the external blocks also allows easy reproduction with common materials resulting in more varied and experimental results. This encourages users to curate their environment through creative play with the shade.

data.name: Speculating Self-governing Robotics in Post-Construction Takeover
data.mainContent: After the design and construction of a residential project, AI takes over as the authority to maintain (upkeep) and reconfigure (make changes) the building. While making changes to the original building, the robots gain sole ownership of the building over time due to the “redesign” exceeding the original design threshold. Additionally, through deep learning, the robots gain complexity from continuous self-replication. They make critical decisions to optimise the building. However, the resultant consequence results in a conflict between human residents and the robotic government of the building. Cats go missing, a suicide occured- will the residents subject or subvert?

data.name: Lucidity
data.mainContent:
A millennium has passed since 2020. A thousand years since the year of the ‘Digital Dissimulation' which foreshadowed the dark future in which the Earth was plunged into as strains of viruses did not stop and continually evolved. Overcrowding remained an issue even with the highest recorded death toll in that year. However, with many losing their loved ones at unexpected places and times, practicing the rituals of funerals and last goodbyes became almost impossible in a world that was bound to an online dimension.
As a result, Lucidity was born. A place where one can enter a metaphysical dimension from anywhere and to be able to be with their loved ones as they pass from this world to the next. Located among the cliffs of what was left standing the forests of Zhangjiajie National Forest Park was the first of its kind. The deceased is digitized before the funeral and memories extracted are separated into 3 beacons: personality, possessions, and power.
Lucidity seeks to provide clarity in a world of confusion so that the deceased can be properly mourned and so that families and friends are not limited to physicality or location when wanting to celebrate and be with those who have passed.

data.name: White Silence
data.mainContent:
After decades of research and technological advancement, the "body revolution" is achieved where humankind has transcended to a form of higher physicality with higher capability and tolerance. Nanobots with healing properties are embedded in their bodies, allowing them to live longer.
However, death is an unavoidable part of mortal life. Humans use this "extra" time to journey to the cemetery in Antarctica where they will part with their loved ones, reflect on their mortal life, and depart from the world after the extraction of the nanobots. These nanobots contain a fragment of their life experience which can be accessed by the next body.
When one departs, the living is left behind. The living can hold services to pray, read and sing as they grieve for what is lost and rejoice at what is gained.

data.name: The Sinister Library
data.mainContent:
Libraries have always been known to be a virtuous space. In 2075, libraries are being privatised. Blinded by the greed for money, some companies have turned to finding ways in setting up secret experiments underground. They have also subtly designed a process that would gain the human test subjects at their own will, unknowingly.
Libraries are the prime target because the public views it as a virtuous space and it is a considerably trusted area that is known to benefit people on almost all types of information. Here, these patrons are now identified as test subjects who are part of certain unethical experiments run by the said companies. They are not necessarily aware of the repercussions and stake.
In order to gain volunteers for these experiments, patrons will be offered monetary incentives that are attractive. These serve as a form of luring device into getting them enticed to the rooms that transports them virtually to the experiments and will only be released until they are done, with duration varying across each experiment. These rooms that host such sinister activities are tucked away in hidden corners with limited access to other members of the public.

data.name: Stewards of the Forest
data.mainContent:
Forest Stewardship is an uncommon concept in Singapore, considering that it is mostly a dense urban built-environment. However, our building plot at Dover has presented us with a rare opportunity to live near a lush forest in close proximity. Hence this project envisions what it is like to create a living space that instills in residents, a common ecological motivation of forest care and ownership amongst community via an effective system of caretaking, and in doing so, establish nature as an asset worth carrying for.
Specifically, the housing units and community spaces will be interconnected with the forest through both digital and hands-on means by leveraging smart technology so as to ease the onboarding process for people who are new to this lifestyle. As a whole, the project hopes to foster stewardship over the forest and discover collective opportunities for human-nature intertwined experiences to occur in such a lifestyle.

data.name: OTW Through T2
data.mainContent:
As one of the world's busiest airports by international passenger and cargo traffic, Changi Airport has a constant flow of people of all ages and from all walks of life. Specifically, in the transit area of Changi Airport, there are a variety of travellers, from restless children, young adults excited for their upcoming flights, or older adults who are fatigued after a long flight, and these travellers each have different needs and wants. After interviewing our friends and family of different ages and occupations, we surmised that our intervention in the transit lounge needs to be delightful, engaging and inclusive to people of all ages and abilities. Moreover, we envisioned our intervention to be sustainable and incorporate gamification using avant-garde technology. Finally, we designed and fabricated an ensemble of carpet from the old Terminal 2, plywood and LEDs that took the shape of a round table.
The AR trivia table allows travellers to find out cool and interesting facts about different parts of the world while playing a fun and interactive adventure game enabled by augmented reality technologies. Not only can those tech-savvy individuals access this AR game on their phones by simply scanning a QR code, but those not familiar with such technology can also be entertained by the captivating lights illuminating the different lines on the carpet, which represent planes travelling on their flight paths in real-time.

data.name: Lux Plantae
data.mainContent: The Lux Plantae, a tabletop plant lamp, is a deconstructed rendition of the familiar Jenga tower. Inspired by plants, it recreates an artificial form of nature to bring about a serene and organic ambience through the interplay of light and shadows while at the same time, still retaining a practical use for reading and work.

data.name: Aurora
data.mainContent: Sized to fit the modest home, the luminaire adds flair to its surroundings, serving both as a conversation starter and the user's self-expression. Layers of planar acrylic sheets covered with dichroic film augments the emitted light with a myriad of alternating colours to create a unique atmosphere within the room. Removable parts add customizability to an otherwise static fixture, offering flexibility in use, from light augmentation, ambience effect, serving as a decorative display piece to functioning as a reading light.

data.name: Build a Lamp
data.mainContent: We explored the usage of having a physical element of play in varying the brightness and characteristics of the light emitted from the luminaire. This was achieved using a collection of modular units that will only light up upon connecting to the others, making the luminaire brighter. The modules can then be swapped out for others with different diffusers or colour temperatures to create different ambiences.​

data.name: Bloom
data.mainContent:
Bloom is a kinetic luminaire that mirrors not only the appearance of a flower but also its blooming mechanism. The flower ostensibly engages in a dialogue with humans by taking on an emotive and socially expressive form, unfolding or retracting its petals when one comes into close contact with it.
Bloom's petal arrangement is achieved with parametric design that simulates the growth of actual flowers, supported by a mechanical movement encoded in lines of C++. All these come together to produce a cool, calming glow, supplied by a single LED bulb, that diffuses from the blue translucent fabric, captivating the audience to watch this alluring display.

data.name: Crux
data.mainContent:
Inspired by Southern Cross constellation, CRUX translates its five brightest star into spheres, balancing the top structure that represents a space in our universe. The sizes and placement of these spheres were a result of translating the size and brightness of the five stars, as well as their relative distance from earth. Crux takes a different shape when viewed from different perspectives, but the five stars will form a cross in most. This encourages viewers to revolve around Crux and examine it from different angles, as there will always be another perspective, like most things in life.
It was a challenge to achieve the desired sophisticated look from simple materials. Different materials from armatures to wood were explored, manufacturing techniques from manual wiring and drilling to 3D printing and laser-cutting were employed.

data.name: Arboreal
data.mainContent:
A sturdy body made of familiar solid wood exuding an elegant presence, Arboreal is inviting to look, touch and feel. With a strong focus on marrying our material choice and craft, we hope that the final form of Arboreal would reflect and celebrate the synergistic effect between light and natural wood.
Our light source is hidden within the wooden facade, allowing the illuminated interior to concentrate light and become the main focal point. It then brings attention to the the natural tone and intricate grains of the surrounding wood pieces, giving the whole a sense of motion and excitement. From various angles, Arboreal allows peeks into its wooden center and at the same time, offers different degree of illumination to its exterior.
Our final product is a humble wooden luminaire that accentuates the beauty of natural wooden textures and exhibits its ability to contribute to the ambiance of a space.

data.name: Danger Zone
data.mainContent: Danger Zone is a generative adversarial model trained to detect the possibilities of danger of any given floor plan by using datasets created from game matches of Counter Strike: Global Offensive. First player shooter games are used to simulate movement of 'terrorists' and 'civilians' within a space, and the varied spatial context allows us to study how the architectural elements could increase survivability. The trained data is subsequently used to generate more CS:GO game maps that are either 'safe' and 'dangerous'.

data.name: Siteless+
data.mainContent: Siteless+ Forms utilizes machine learning to identify and create new forms for design inspiration from existing data. Inspiration and style of representation originate from the Siteless: 1001 Building Forms by François Blanciak. It is an exploration of the relationship between language and form with input sketches, descriptions and a Python machine learning algorithm. Siteless+ is imagined as a form of social media in which designers and architects are able to seek creative form inspiration through machine learning to produce new forms. The project consists of a machine learning model to recognize input sketches, morph these sketches into new forms that retain main features and a simple understanding of descriptive words which aid in its form generation as well as image recognition.

data.name: Building Clouds
data.mainContent: Silicone Mould Plaster Casting was used to create stackable spheres to aggregate into cloud inspired forms.

data.name: Katana
data.mainContent: Katana was the result of reimagining what a joint could be. In this project, form took precedence over function  as 4 katanas are held together by an intricate central node, inspired by Japanese and Chinese motifs. While having a strong aesthetic, the joint is also sturdy and the angles at which each "katana" rotates around the node can be customized with swappable parts. Fabrication methods include laser cutting, laser engraving and water jet cutting. This project taught us how sometimes by questioning what something could be and why it is the way it is, we can design something completely novel with fresh perspectives.

data.name: DreamScape
data.mainContent:
We all know what it’s like to dream. Whether it’s a good dream or a bad dream, a dream is a sequence of thoughts, images, and emotions that occur during sleep. While we may not always remember our dreams, they can be a powerful source of creativity. Dreams can provide new insights into our lives and our world. However, with the rapid development in the field of artificial intelligence (AI) in recent years, creativity found in dreams is not limited to humans but has some semblance in AI as well. This does not mean that AI is going to replace the artist in us architects but instead, it becomes a tool which pushes our creativity and our perception of our world further, leading to unique and unexpected designs.
DreamScape is an Instagram filter that adds noise to reality, producing unexpected results that are kaleidoscopic and dream-like. It distorts space and reality, questions perceptions and is a tool to study the world through a new lens, inspiring creativity. So don't let your dreams just be dreams.

data.name: Casa Sabio
data.mainContent:
In 2022, our founders had an epiphany - to revolutionise the hotel industry, to redefine relaxation. In the past, going for a holiday meant that you still had to plan, schedule and make arrangements on top of your daily duties. Our founders found that ridiculously ironic, why does wanting to take a break add more stress instead?
Imagine getting a real break from the hustle and bustle of life by not having to think, plan or make decisions - yet with everything suited to your needs and preferences! How wonderful would that be! Our founders wanted to turn that into a reality, hence they conceptualised this idea of having a staycation experience in an unmanned hotel empowered by artificial intelligence. That was how Casa Sabio came about - casa for house and sabio for intelligent - it would be the first hotel with a mind of its own, planning everything for you from the day you intend to come until the day you leave our hotel.
Welcome to the first ever AI-powered hotel in the world. Enjoy a world-class, one-of-a-kind experience at Casa Sabio whereby you can enjoy a maximum peace of mind with all the decisions and thinking done for you by AI specially catered to your needs, preferences and habits. Find out more here: https://sl194.github.io/aaid_website/
Finally, we will explore the concept of design authorship in the context of robotic architecture. This will involve examining the ways in which robotics can be used to create novel and innovative designs, as well as the potential benefits and challenges of using robotics in this way. We will also consider the ways in which robotic systems can be programmed to collaborate with human designers, and the potential impact on the overall design process.
